indicators.justification:
There is no regulatory framework for collecting and publishing beneficial ownership data on companies. Thus, company beneficial ownership information is not available as open data, neither is structured. Bill 341/2020 is expected to regulate this kind of information, which will not be publicly available (1) (2).

Current and available information on companies provides general information regarding the commercial registry, e.g., indicates the company's identification number, status, type of company, and organization (3). It also has a section with the owner's information, such as the company name or name.

Although the Registro Único Empresarial (RUES) has identification information such as the identification card or tax identification number (NIT), it is not possible to know the beneficial ownership information when there are intermediate companies or legal entities as owners.

## Sources
(1) Bill 341 of 2020. Bills registered 2020 – 2021. Senate of the Republic. Congress of the Republic of Colombia. http://leyes.senado.gov.co/proyectos/index.php/textos-radicados-senado/p-ley-2020-2021/2113-proyecto-de-ley-341-de-2020
(2) Beneficial ownership legislation introduced to Colombian senate. STEP. https://www.step.org/industry-news/beneficial-ownership-legislation-introduced-colombian-senate
(3) Public user guide on the RUES website. http://www.rues.org.co/GuiaUsuarioPublico/index.html

indicators.justification:
As there is no open dataset in the strict sense, it is not possible to report a unique identifier for each company different from the company registry number. In other words, the website of the Registro Único Empresarial (RUES) has the general information of owners organized by fields, but each record is separate and not as a dataset (1). 

Although the Unified Corporate Registry (RUES) has identification information such as ID or tax identification numbers (NIT), it is not possible to know the beneficial ownership information when there are intermediate companies or legal entities as owners. 

According to Article 19 of the Commercial Code of Colombia, people who do commerce must register acts, books, and documents in the Commercial Registry (2). However, this information is not available through the Registro Único Empresarial (RUES). To do so, certificates must be requested from the Chamber of Commerce of the city of the registration of the Natural Person, Legal Entity, or Commercial Establishment. There the dates, the registration number, or the keywords for the registration search are specified, but the textual copy certificate has a cost.

The information of the commercial registries is updated every year, in accordance with item 2.1.3.1, Title VIII, Sole Circular of the Superintendency of Industry and Commerce, which requires the annual renewal of the registries (3). Historical data are not available on the RUES website to record changes over time, but they are through the Chamber of Commerce website related to the company's commercial registry. These are not for free; a certificate costs USD$ 1.61 approximately (4). 

As previously mentioned, the search tool allows access to a company's registry, but not to the dataset. Also, each record, not the data as a whole, can be downloaded in XLSX format, but not in CSV or JSON. For this reason, the free and available information is fragmented and limited.

## Sources
(1) Sole Business Register web page (RUES). http://www.rues.org.co/
(2) Article 19, Chapter I, Title I On the People Who Commerce, First Book, Decree 410 of 1971, Commercial Code of Colombia. https://www.ccb.org.co/content/download/4599/48339/version/2/file/Codigo+de+Comercio.pdf
(3) Item 2.1.3., Title VIII, Sole Circular of the Superintendency of Industry and Commerce. https://www.sic.gov.co/sites/default/files/normatividad/042021/T%C3%ADtulo%20VIII%20CamarasdeComercioabril2021.pdf
(4)  Get the certificates here. Bogotá Chamber of Commerce. https://www.ccb.org.co/Inscripciones-y-renovaciones/Todo-sobre-renovaciones/Adquiera-certificados-aqui

The Colombian National Department of Statistics (1) has the historical vital statistics information on births and deaths in Colombia. In the presentation (2) of these statistics, you can see the technical and methodological considerations of the project.

In addition, in the technical bulletin (3) of the statistics, DANE adopted the latest version of the International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems (ICDH). Health-Related Problems (ICD-10), used for the coding of the basic cause of death, moving from the ICD-10 to the ICD-10.
of death, moving from ICD-10 v2015 to ICD-10 v2018.

In order to have information on statistics, DANE has created a data viewer (4) where the variables of births and deaths in Colombia can be known. These viewers also have user manuals to facilitate the use of the information.

indicators.justification:
The information on the doses applied by department of the country is found in a government database (1), however this dataset does not contain sufficient information to know in detail the application of vaccines in the country, such as the age of the vaccinated persons, their gender/sex, among others. In addition, the dataset, despite being in an updated spreadsheet, does not have an explicit license for its use or how the data should be read.

There is a government-driven visualization dashboard (2) where there is a wealth of information, but this cannot be downloaded in machine-readable formats.

As this dataset exists, it is very likely that there are other datasets with much more extensive information. It is expected that this information will be published on the MiVacuna portal website (3).

The Universidad de los Andes has also created a platform for the advancement of vaccination (4).

The Agustin Codazzi Geographical Institute, through its cadastre subdirectorate and the open data portal (1) has geographic and cadastral databases. alphanumeric by department. indicators.justification:
The Ministry of Finance of Colombia publishes the decree of the presidency of the republic where the general budget of the nation is allocated (1) and the budget execution reports (2) are also in pdf format distributed by months of the year. These documents are in pdf format and are therefore difficult to reuse. Namely, there are no multiple budget datasets. On the contrary, the data are not structured in tables, much less in machine-processable formats.

Efforts have been made to have an economic transparency portal (3) where budget execution can be found by sector, subject, entity, in a structured manner.

The available online lobbying registration data is reduced to the Public Registry of Lobbyists of the House of Representatives, which contains the name of the lobbyist or entity, address, and contact (1). 

On the one hand, this data does not contain participant details for each interaction between a lobbyist and a public official, information about lobbyists' goals for lobbying activities, dates and time details for each interaction between a lobbyist and a public official, information about the topic of each interaction between a lobbyist and a public official, nor information about the money spent on each interaction between a lobbyist and a public official.

On the other hand, the data evaluated are not comprehensive, since the Senate, in the case of the legislative branch, or the executive and judicial branches do not yet have a regulation on lobbying and available data. Bill 410 of 2021 is expected to cover the whole public sector, and obtain information such as identification; interest promoted, defended, or represented; lobbying client; meetings and travel information of authorities (2). 

In general terms, the information available is in Spanish and free of charge. However, it does not contain unique identifiers for lobbyists, public officials nor lobbying clients. Likewise, it does not refer to open license usage and does not have open and accessible tools to explore the data. Since the information is in a table on the website, it is not machine-processable and is as a whole. In any case, the table contains 13 records only.

Even though an annual update of the data is estimated, there is no content from 2019 to date. However, historical data is available from one year before the enactment of the MD-2348 of 2011 resolution to 2018, allowing changes over time to be recorded.

indicators.justification:
There are strategies through government regulations to reuse data, however there is no long-term framed strategy, these are the Guide for the use and exploitation of Open Data in Colombia (1), Resolution 1519 of 2020 (2) and Conpes 3920 of 2018 (3). These documents reflect that the reuse of data should be done mainly with the publication of data in a format that allows this purpose.

In the national open data portal (4) there is a section on the use of data so that any user of the portal can have greater knowledge and use of these. 

Some of the calls presented for the reuse of data are: Calidatón to improve the quality of your entity's data to make better decisions and promote transparency aimed at public officials (5), use and Calidatón of open data published by Covid19 (6), Bank of Challenges of Public and Private Entities to propose challenges for the beneficiaries of the MinTIC training program in Data Science (7), Application for pilot projects of analytics and Big Data by public entities (8).

indicators.justification:
In Colombia, the IV National Open Government Plan 2020-2022 (1) was published, which establishes commitments in relation to the publication of open data.

According to Decree 1064 of 2020 (2), Article 26, the Directorate of Digital Government of the Ministry of Information Technologies must "Develop and implement policies to promote and facilitate that the State makes available to citizens data sets that promote the development of innovation processes and technology-based entrepreneurship through the use of Information and Communication Technologies". However, there is no evidence in the expenditures and budget allocation of the Ministry, of the distribution by directorates of the entity.

The Directorate of Digital Government publishes Colombia's national data portal (3) and the Guide for the use and exploitation of Open Data in Colombia for the publication of data by obligated subjects in the country (4). However, there is no evidence of statements by the Minister of Information Technology or other members of the government regarding the importance of open data. Despite the fact that it is a public policy of the country.

indicators.justification:
Law 1712 of 2014 (1) establishes "Any public entity, including those belonging to all Branches of Public Power, at all levels of the state structure, central or decentralized by services or territorially, in the national, departmental, municipal and district orders," therefore the obligated subjects in data management also include municipalities, regions and local governments. However, there is not much information regarding the specific data management by these territorial entities.

As for some initiatives at the territorial level, one can find the government of the city of Bogotá (2), promoted by the mayor's office. In addition, in the National Open State Plan (3), there are some commitments to the publication of data by territorial governments such as the Open Data Platform - Open Tenders Bank of the Mayor's Office of Palmira, Active Transparency, and Open Data of the Department of Valle del Cauca (Governor's Office of Valle del Cauca).

As an example of the creation of a territorial public data policy, the Mayor's Office of the city of Bogotá published Decree 189 of 2020 (4) where it establishes guidelines on transparency, integrity, and anti-corruption measures in the entities and agencies of the district order, also Directive 005 of 2020 (5) of the Mayor's Office of Bogotá, D.C. establishes guidelines for the opening and use of data of each entity of the district.

indicators.justification:
Despite the fact that Colombia currently has a guide for quality standards and interoperability of open data, the document does not contain a clear strategy to perform interoperation between datasets variables in the country. Specifically the localized data for political financing, interest and asset declarations, lobbying, public consultations and RTI performance do not contain interoperable variables.

The websites of public entities have varied information, however they do not use identifiers for different actors and factors according to their field of action, so there are no common identifiers either.

indicators.justification:
There are guidelines on the commercial registry (1)(2), which provides general information on companies (3)(4). However, there is no regulatory framework for the collection and publication of beneficial ownership data on companies. The commercial registry indicates the company's identification number, its current status, type of company, and organization (5). It also has a section with the owner's information, such as the company name or name.

Even so, it is not possible to know the beneficial owners behind the legal entities or intermediate companies except for the legal representatives and their powers. In this sense, the information of the natural persons who have control and ownership over the companies is not requested and is not available.

The general information of the commercial registries is centralized in the page of the Registro Único Empresarial (RUES) (6). However, the data are fragmented since they must be accessed one by one and as long as the name of the company or its identification is known (7).

On October 29, 2020, Bill 341/20 was filed in the Senate of the Republic for the registry of beneficial ownership (8). This will be managed by the National Tax and Customs Directorate (DIAN, for its acronym in Spanish) through the Sole Registry of Final Beneficiaries (RUB, for its acronym in Spanish) (9). The information will not be accessible to the public, but only to inspection, control, and surveillance entities or those with fiscal or disciplinary investigation functions. 

On June 08, 2021, it was approved in First Debate (10), so it has three pending debates to become law. This law expects to respond to the Financial Action Task Force's (FATF's) recommendations on anti-corruption and anti-money laundering. Therefore, incomplete, outdated, or non-compliant information will result in sanctions to the company.

indicators.justification:
The Interoperability Framework for Digital Government "...defines the set of principles, recommendations and guidelines that guide the political and legal, organizational, semantic and technical efforts of the entities in order to facilitate the secure and efficient exchange of information" (1). In that sense, it provides a maturity model on good practices for data sharing between Digital Citizen Services. 

The framework proposes different interactions called interoperability domains: Political-Legal, Organizational, Semantic, and Technical (2). The last two refer to best practices for information sharing and requirements for information flow, respectively.

The framework mentions that it can be applied to all public and private entities, but also foreign governments and the academic community that perform interoperability with Digital Government (2). Interoperability revolves around the interaction of citizens, public and private entities with the State. However, it is not specific about the type of information that can be shared with the State. Nor does it contemplate the exchange of information within the private sector.

indicators.justification:
In Colombia, there is a legal framework regarding personal data implemented through Law 1581 of 2012 (1). This Law dictates general provisions for data protection. The framework provides data subjects with rights of choice or consent and provides data subjects with rights to access and correct data about themselves. But the Framework doesn't explicitly cover the protection of location-related data.

Also there are initiatives such as Sandbox, a preventive, supervised and temporary experimentation space for those interested in developing artificial intelligence (AI) (2). Sandbox is a preventive, supervised, and temporary experimentation space based on AI projects to create collaborative compliance solutions to personal data protection standards. (https://www.sic.gov.co/sandbox-microsite)

##Sources

Law 1712 of 2014 on Transparency and Access to Public Information (1) establishes a framework for the application of guidelines and good practices in the development of strategies for openness and reuse of open data, for that the Guide for the use and exploitation of Open Data in Colombia (2) by public officials was created.

In addition, Resolution 1519 of 2020 (3) of the ICT Ministry establishes, among other aspects, the standards for the publication of information, including the technical conditions for the opening of open data in Colombia.

The legal frameworks define the concepts of open data, they are not explicit with the use of open licenses. And specifically the Guide for the use and exploitation of Open Data is explicit about the formats in which the information should be structured, and about the use of some national standards. However, there is no much reference to training for public officials on data issues.

indicators.justification:
The regulatory framework regarding lobbying does not provide a sufficient basis for the collection and publication of data on lobbying activities. The regulations are dispersed and do not cover the entire public sector. In the first place, the second paragraph of article 144 of the Constitution establishes that the sessions of Congress must be public, and the exercise of lobbying shall be regulated by law (1). Chapter IV of Law 1474 of 2011 requires information of demarches in case of crime or disciplinary misconduct (2). Finally, Resolution MD-2348 of 2011 of the House of Representatives establishes a Public Registry of Lobbyists for that corporation (3).

Of these laws, Resolution MD-2348 of 2011 provides information on the companies and individuals that have been registered in the Public Registry of Lobbyists for each term of the congressmen (four years), but this is reduced to name, address, and contact (4). In this regard, the registry on the page has the information for the period 2014-2018, so the data for the current period (2018-2022) or its legislatures to date are not available. On the other hand, this registry is limited to the House of Representatives, so it does not extend to the Senate to cover the legislative branch, but neither the executive branch (presidency, governorships, and mayors' offices) nor the judicial branch. 

There have been repeated attempts to regulate the practice, since its informality has effects on its operation, irregularities, and sanctions (5). For the time being, current regulations on lobbying are considered lacking in "integrity" (6) or "less ambitious model" and restricted to one legislative chamber (compared to other countries) (7).

Currently, Bill 410/21 (8) is underway, which seeks to regulate lobbying and create the Public Registry of Lobbyists (9). Its objective is to promote transparency and equal opportunities for participation in decision-making in public administration, as well as the promotion of interests in the branches of public power and State agencies (Article 1).

Unlike Resolution MD-2348 of 2011, the Draft Law concerns the three branches of public power (legislative, executive, and judicial), control bodies, autonomous and independent agencies, and the Armed Forces (Article 3). In addition, it stipulates a minimum level of disclosure of information: identification; interest promoted, defended, or represented; lobbying client; meetings and travel information of authorities (Article 2). 

Finally, it provides consultation and provision for free of information from the Public Registry of Lobbyists, which, in addition to the lobbyist's data, includes his or her lobbying activities and record of relations with the authorities (Article 5).

## Sources
(1) Political Constitution of Colombia. Presidency of Colombia. http://wsp.presidencia.gov.co/Normativa/Documents/Constitucion-Politica-Colombia.pdf
(2) Law 1474 of 2011. Administrative Department of the Civil Service. https://www.funcionpublica.gov.co/eva/gestornormativo/norma.php?i=43292
(3) Resolution number MD-2348 of 2011. House of Representatives. Congress of the Republic of Colombia. https://www.camara.gov.co/camara/visor?doc=/sites/default/files/2017-07/RES%20MD2348%20Reg%20Cabilderos.pdf
(4) Public Registry of Lobbyists (Contact information). House of Representatives. Congress of the Republic of Colombia. https://www.camara.gov.co/registro-publico-de-cabilderos-datos-de-contacto
(5) Simón Suárez Salazar. 2014. Lobbying and its functioning as an informal practice in the Congress of the Republic of Colombia. Monography. Pontificia Universidad Javeriana. Bogotá. https://repository.javeriana.edu.co/handle/10554/18580 . p. 37. 
(6) Julián Amorocho Becerra. (October 29, 2018). This is how lobbying is done (legally) in Colombia. El Colombiano. https://www.elcolombiano.com/colombia/asi-se-hace-el-lobby-legalmente-en-colombia-IA9570318
(7) David Córdova. (July-August 2018). Lobbying regulation in Latin America: between transparency and participation. Nueva Sociedad. https://nuso.org/articulo/regulacion-del-lobby-en-america-latina/
(8) Congreso Visible.  Bills. "Whereby the exercise of lobbying is regulated, and the Public Registry of Lobbyists is created. indicators.justification:
Products or services exist that use company information to support due diligence, but by non-structured data, if not fragmented and disjointed. In fact, there are not official open government datasets for this, but especially a federated database con the whole information. As an example, the open data portal of the Government has some datasets regarding due diligence (e.g., a dataset of dismissed proponents) provided by a chamber of commerce, yet not by all of these (1).

Due diligence is carried out through the validation and cross of both international restrictive lists, sanction lists, and public registry databases (2). By the way, in Colombia, there is no regulatory framework on the lists and databases that must be consulted (3). However, the management of due diligence and the submission of Suspicious Transaction Reports to the Financial Information and Analysis Unit (UIAF) is mandatory (3).

Initially, Due Diligence was implemented in the financial sector through the Organic Statute of the Financial System of the Financial Superintendence. Afterward, it was extended to other sectors with LAFT (i.e., Money Laundering and Financing of Terrorism) risks (4).

Regarding national lists and public registry databases, due diligence services work with judicial records (Police) (5), fiscal records (Comptroller General) (6), disciplinary and contractual records plus the above (Attorney General's Office) (7), State Debtors Bulletin (General Accounting Office of the Nation) (8), the sanction resolutions declaring a fictitious supplier (from the National Tax and Customs Directorate) (9), among others (3).

The queries are performed with info such as identity card, tax identification number (NIT), company name, etc. The information provided by those entities is public and free of charge, but it is dispersed and decentralized according to the entity that produces it. Due to the above, the updating of the information varies.

indicators.justification:
Colombia's public procurement agency, Colombia Compra Eficiente, has made some dashboards of visualizations of public contracting in Colombia (1) (2). In addition, in the context of the COVID-19 emergency, a Dashboard for visualization of emergency contracts was published (3).

However, there is no evidence of the use of red flags to detect irregularities in contracts. There is also no evidence of data analysis to provide access and empower minority or marginalized groups to public procurement processes, despite the existence of circulars (4) (5) and a decree that seeks to strengthen this aspect (6). There is also no evidence that public procurement data are analyzed to support sustainable procurement, only the Guide for environmentally sustainable public procurement by Colombia Compra Eficiente (7).

There are multiple projects promoted by civil society to monitor public procurement, among them some journalistic and anti-corruption exercises such as the one carried out by the journalists' network Red Palta (8) that used the dashboard for visualization and publication of emergency contracts to carry out journalistic investigations and Transparency International Colombia carried out a project together with other civil society organizations to analyze public contracts of the pandemic (9).
